posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
The Hardy Polymath


Image source: https://i.pinimg.com/originals/d7/61/51 ... 006e8c.jpg


Build notes:
Greetings all. 

This is a fairly simple build draft, High Intelligence Wizard with Epic Damage Reduction III (EDR III). 

It uses: 
- Gnome Race for Wizard as favored class to avoid multiclass penalties, and +cons bonus to help obtain EDR III.
- Fighter to help reduce general epic feat usage to obtain EDR III
- Rogue for skill dumps, Evasion [and Uncanny Dodge]

Apart from the requirements for EDR III, Epic Mage Armor and Epic Warding, it attempts to put everything else into Intelligence.

There is space for Spell Focus/Greater Spell Focus in two schools of magic, or one school of magic and Spell Pen/Greater Spell Pen. 

I chose Necromancy and Evocation in this build. 

He aims to be a hardy and versatile high DC spell caster, and I have chosen to make this fellow a generalist. 

One might very successfully argue choosing a school of specialty would make the build stronger but from an RP perspective, I want this fellow to be a true Polymath, a learned scholar and master in many fields.

He doesn't look to frontline like Mestil's Half-Dead Juggernaut, and prefers not to be hit in combat, however he makes himself extremely difficult to kill by having the base HP of a melee warrior with EDR III, high saves vs spells and evasion.

Spell penetration 35+1d20 [39+1d20 if SP/GSP feats chosen]

Extend Spell/Silent Spell/Empower Spell/Maximize Spell

From a min/maxing perspective, I personally would likely keep 3 Rogue for Uncanny Dodge I.  There is just too much to gain in keeping all the AC intact IMO. 

Otherwise, a lovely read and I want to replace Fighter with CoT ... but I cannot which makes me a little grumpy :)

posts.author: Ten Pura
posts.content:
Orion,

If the 2nd fighter level is pushed to 39, you could shuffle some skill points around for a higher discipline. It would delay EDR III, but the reduced vulnerability to knockdown would probably be worth it, but that's my opinion, YMMV.

I normally only take enough ranks in craft weapon to get the large bones too drop from skeletons to make wands, in environments where that's not available. For this build, you only need 2 ranks, unless you're going for something else.

I normally only invest 10 ranks in lore. Works wonders at the early levels and not needed as much at higher levels.

You're right about the Mord's resistance. The breach part will still happen, but it takes a level 27 caster to have a 5% chance of dispelling other effects with Mord's. A UMD user will be unable to dispel your non-beach-able buffs. This means you have haste, expeditious, and improved invisibility (to name a few) AFTER the Mord's from martial casters (caster level 26 or below)/UMD'rs. So no, the dreaded Nightshade cannot take your haste/invis/expeditious/bull's/fox's/et al.

Overall, a very solid caster wizard build.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Ten Pura for your suggestions

I think pushing back the fighter level is an excellent idea. This guy is still gonna be knocked down regularly in caster mode unless he has knockdown immune boots/other item, however if he polymorphs I believe his Iron Golem form with damage shields up is going to have some resistance to knockdown. It could help a little against called shots on second to fifth attacks.
Thanks for educating me on the craft weapon for wands, I've made the adjustments.
I pumped lore up but that's because I wasn't sure what else to do with the skill points, I've left it at *only* 12(25) which can be buffed with spells of course.
Thanks for crunching the numbers with the dispels. For me it was just more a feel thing whilst playing, like it felt x caster levels was Mord resistant, without fully understanding the mechanics.
The reason why I like some resistance to Mords from UMD casters is that it is easy for module creators to generate random Mords scrolls on enemies to remove all your buffs.
The Dreaded Nightshade (High ISR Monk/SD/Assassin) is going to be annoying for sure, if this fellow were to face her.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Interesting take on wizard with all that HPs and EDR!
My input is only minor: Although strength is low, a wizard with fighter levels screams armor, shield and Auto still. But that will need som reworking and less DC for more AC.
The skill table can be fine tuned some, especially how far you want to go with trap skills. UMD 33 is for care free spell casting from scrolls. I am not sure if you need that with a wizard. The UMD target for items depends on the level of magic item properties.
All in all a nice build!

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Funny, I just built the exact same creature a couple of weeks ago but never posted it.  Very min-maxed, but it worked.  I ended up going tri-focused with ESFs in 3 different spell schools.  EDR III, 34 Int, et cetera, et cetera.

However, I ended up becoming disillusioned (again) with wizard/sorcerer spell schools of Evocation and Illusion.  The good wizard evocation spells don't really use DCs (ILMS, IGMS, Ice Storm, Bigbys, etc), and the Illusion line (Phantasmal Killer and Weird) are fort saves with conditionals.  Might as well go with Necromancy and remove the conditionals and just make it a straight fort save.  

I can post the end result if you want to see how I approached the issue.

posts.author: Ten Pura
posts.content:
GDL,
In wizard builds, I sometimes take SF: Evocation, but early. As you stated, most of the best Evocation spells don't have a save, but until the wizard grows into those, the SF: Evocation can help those Burning Hands or Scintillating Spheres land.

Likewise, Tasha's is amazing at low levels, but increased availability of immunity to mind spells, combined with basically every boss ever having immunity to mind spells makes later Enchantment school spells mostly useless.

Conversely, Necromancy doesn't start to shine until mid to late wizard levels, and continues to be the reason that immunity to death magic is highly desirable.

Conjuration is situationally useful. Grease is effective against high-SR creatures (even SR 67+). Web, Flame Arrow, and Stinking Cloud are also situationally useful, but above level 3, the effects of improved DC's for Conjuration become less significant. No one with 7+ hit dice makes a save against Cloudkill. Acid Fog allows a save to resist the slow effect, doesn't change the damage. Meanwhile, the Planar Binding spells only have a save when binding a single outsider (Dismissal is generally better at this). I would only recommend a Conjuration focus if facing enemies with significant SR, especially hordes of outsiders with significant SR.

For the remaining schools, Divination only has Feeblemind. Abjuration has Dismissal and Banishment. Illusion has Weird, but immunity to fear stops it, and same with Phantasmal Killer. Transmutation has Flesh to Stone and Slow.

As a note for other readers, these recommendations are for arcane spell casters. Divine Casters can get some milage out of a +6 DC Implosion (Evocation) or Storm of Vengeance (Conjuration).

This isn't to say that a character can't be built differently, but if you're looking for the TL;DR version: take ESF: Necromancy; don't invest in the others.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Ten Pura / GDL /  Mick / Conlaoch
I have had similar advice SF/GSF/ESF: Necromancy tends to be the best choice, if a spell focus is chosen.
I have had similar experiences to GDL in that a lot of the spells when I use arcane casters I used were no DC spells like bigby's, ILMS/IGMS, damage shield/shapechange, summons/BBoD etc.
Its why I haven't really pursued the ESF line with this build for a Tri-focus or Tetra-focus and just pumped Int up to make all spells better + get bonus spells/skill points and gone for EDR III/EW/EMA/Toughness to boost up defenses. At least the d4 hit die issue with wizards is mitigated by this. 
Still/Auto Still I-III is also a very good choice if one wishes to equip armor/shield to boost AC up, I haven't pursued it due to the base Str 7 and the lack of feats remaining but that is an alternative to boost AC up. If one has a socket item component to the module/PW, sometimes items can be socketed to have low arcane spell failure and weight. If all else fails maybe an elven chainmail or chain shirt might help if more AC is desired. 

GDL - would be delighted to see your draft if you have the time to post it up.

If the DC Evocation spells are somewhat lacklustre it doesn't seem sensible to overly invest in them
I would have thought Incendiary Cloud/Sunburst, Meteor Swarm, Delayed Blast Fireball etc might be useful but sometimes one gets surprises in life. 
I presume at high levels the damage output is simply not enough, it looks like a lot of the damage is capped at 20d6-25d6 and one is better off spamming that wand of ILMS.

I also realised is with 35 caster levels is that I can drop extend spell for another spell focus feat. 

I can rearrange things so that this SF/GSF can be conjuration (for useful crowd control spells -> grease/web/stinking cloud, and evards/flame arrow DC boosts), and the SF can be enchantment (charm, hold, mind fog, dominate monster) and drop Evocation as a spell focus given enough damage can be dealt no save spells like ILMS and IGMS and Evards.

That gives the build SF/GSF: Necromancy and Conjuration, and SF: Enchantment and SF: Illusion (free from gnome)

What do you think?

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Not that you can assume it will be in place, but most modules/PWs have options for basic Spell Focus (first tier). I would generally not recommend spending a single Feat in a Spell Focus outside of places that have secondary benefits. You would likely be better off taking a metamagic feat that offers book management options or ancillary benefits. I would take still or silent myself giving you a +1, +2 and +3 spell slot option.

This all said, I am not drawn to arcane casters so my experience is limited with them.

Thanks Zanithar for your message and I agree Metamagic before Spell Foci.
The build has 10 pre-epic feats + 1 free scribe scroll. 
3 feats are used for metamagic (Silent/Empower/Maximize - for the +1 +2 +3 spell option - extend is probably non-essential in a 35 caster level build), 
2 for crafting (free Scribe Scroll/Craft Wand), 
1 used for Toughness, to get the HP to 400+ which I like, and why not, its a fighter's HP on a high DC wizard. 

This leaves 5 pre-epic feats to spend.
With 35 caster levels and Int 36->48 I'd like to take the opportunity to take feats which improve spell casting, either spell penetration or spell foci to improve DC.
Other feats I considered were +save feats (ie LoH/Great Fortitude/Lightning Reflexes), Resist Energy or Skill Foci (such as Concentration)
But tanking wont be his ideal primary role, with low AC + no crit immunity, this is best left to the likes of Mestil's Half-Dead Juggernaut and other Arcane Caster / PMs, I thought this is a nice opportunity to make a few spells have DC boosts to make em more effective

At the moment I'm leaning towards SF/GSF: Necromancy and Enchantment + SF: Conjuration or Evocation, still haven't decided, I guess it will depend on my spell slinging style as I playtest. 

Btw the build is a joy to play once a solution to the Str 7 encumbrance issue is found. I've got this guy to level 8 with playtesting, and the HP + survivability makes this guy feel like an 'Iron Cannon' rather than a Glass one.
